message.content:
We can “read between the lines” of the many ancestor–descendant facts. In short, if we trace one long chain we eventually observe that two different “branches” join at the same person. One branch comes from Michelle and the other from Stephanie.

For example, two parts of the overall family tree are these:
• Michelle is given as an ancestor of Judy (fact 51) and Judy is an ancestor of Brandon (fact 36), and Brandon is an ancestor of Charles (fact 33). (Also note that fact 1, “Alexis is Charles’s ancestor,” plus facts 49 (“Joe is Alexis’s ancestor”) and 56 (“Julie is Anthony’s descendant”) help us build up another branch.)
• On the other hand, we are told that “Stephanie is Joyce’s ancestor” (fact 24) and “Joyce is Amy’s ancestor” (fact 31). Continuing the long chain (see facts 14, 17, 20, …, 47, 50, 12, 3, 2, 8, …, 58, 29, …, 59, 18, …, 48, 60, 55, 37, 27, 23, 56, 57) we eventually reach Charles (via the chain: Anthony → Julie → Joe → Alexis → Charles).

That is, both Michelle (via Judy → Brandon → Charles) and Stephanie (via Joyce, …, Anthony → Julie → Joe → Alexis → Charles) are ancestors of Charles. In other words, Michelle and Stephanie “come from” two totally different branches that meet at Charles (among many possible common descendants).

Thus, Michelle and Stephanie share a common descendant and are not in an ancestor–descendant relation with each other.

The correct answer is therefore option 2.

<ANSWER>2</ANSWER>
